Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Page Quinton of The University of Missouri to conduct a research project in Geoscience during the summer of 2013 at the Geological Survey of New South Wales in Sydney. The project title is "Constraining Global Sea Surface Temperatures Trends during the Late Ordovician Period in New South Wales Australia." The host scientist is Dr. Ian Percival.

This project establishes the first high-resolution sea surface temperature record of the Australian continent during the Late Ordovician (a time period from 454 to 443 million years ago) using conodont elements (the teeth-like structures located in the gills of a small marine animal, referred to as conodonts) collected from New South Wales, Australia. Previous work along these lines has largely been conducted on rocks from North America making it difficult to determine if observed patterns were global or regional. These results have implications for the role atmospheric carbon dioxide on climate evolution, the timing of Ordovician glaciation, and the relationship between glaciation and the mass extinction event at the end of the Ordovician Period. Furthermore, knowledge of the global climate has societal relevance. Mechanism which governed past changes in global climate, continue to do so today. A better understanding of them will contribute to better predictions of possible changes going forward especially on a long time scale.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. In addition, the knowledge and experience gained by the Fellow will inform and enrich educational experience of the students in the courses she teaches with an emphasis on uprooting misconceptions and misunderstandings about the behavior of climatic systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My project focused on estimating sea surface temperature trends and climate variability during the Ordovician Period (485- 444 Ma) by establishing the first oxygen isotopic record for New South Wales. A second objective, to measure carbon isotopic values across the same interval, was added once my research began. 

To accomplish these objectives I worked with Doctor Ian Percival of the Geological Survey of New South Wales. We spent a week visiting locations in east-central New South Wales to collect rock samples. The rest of my time in Australia was spent processing the samples at the WB Clarke Geoscience Centre and examining the fossil collections at the Australian Museum in Sydney and Geoscience Australia in Canberra. Once I returned to the University of Missouri I analyzed the samples I collected and processed while in Australia.

Initial results suggest that the oxygen and carbon isotopic values from ~481 to 448 million years ago in New South Wales are similar to those previously reported from central Australia. But, oxygen isotopic values are on average lower than those from the mid-continent US. This difference suggests either temperature or seawater chemistry differences between the US and Australia during the Ordovician. This observation should be taken into account when interpreting oxygen isotopic values from Australia.

I documented a slight increase in oxygen isotopic values after 460 million years ago that could be attributed to 1) a local or global increase in the oxygen isotopic composition of seawater through the Ordovician or 2) a decrease in average sea surface temperatures of ~4°C. A confounding factor is that the conodont elements (the teeth-like structures located in the gills of a small jawless marine animal) used to obtain the oxygen isotopic values are affected by the life history of the organism. Ecological differences among conodont species, like the water depth or temperature at which the organism lived, would result in oxygen isotopic differences. To illustrate; the Early/Middle Ordovician conodont species that I analyzed might have lived in shallower warmer waters than those analyzed for the Late Ordovician thereby biasing the Early/Middle Ordovician oxygen isotopic results to lower oxygen isotopic values and creating an artificial increase through the Ordovician. The issue could be resolved if a single conodont species was used to obtain the entire oxygen isotopic trend but none of the conodont species sampled were found at every location sampled. My future research extending the temporal coverage of the oxygen isotopic record from locations within the US might help resolve these issues. If a similar increase were observed in the US it would suggest that the observation is not an artifact and reflects climatic or ocean chemistry changes during the Ordovician.
